The Web is constantly on the move, even if your users browsers aren't. Often, developers have to ignore new APIs due to issues with backward compatibility. Half of the development schedule is spent on building; the other half is spent checking IE8.

Compatability will never be free, but it can certainly be cheaper. Since Grim is built on Web Workers, it can't help you with your IE problems – but it can help you in the future. New technologies like WebSockets, WebRTC, user motion-trackers, and head-mounted displays will integrate directly into Grimwire without changing how you write software.

Grimwire acts as an intermediary between your app and the page. By constraining applications into the server-side, Grimwire can interpret requests and responses according to the features of the environment. This means hosts can apply themes, features can cleanly degrade, and interfaces can operate in any context.

Server-side-only doesn't mean dumb UIs. Grimwire provides a toolset for building rich real-time UIs without violating REST principles. As a result, most tools available to local servers are available to remote servers as well – the only difference is latency!
